fullProgramDescription: The Neuroscience major is designed to provide a rigorous foundation in the principles of neuroscience. The program is structured to provide a broad understanding of the field, including the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying nervous system function, as well as the behavioral and cognitive aspects of neuroscience. Students are exposed to a range of courses that cover the structure and function of the nervous system, from the molecular to the systems level.
shortProgramDescription: The Neuroscience B.S. program at UCLA offers a comprehensive education in the principles and practices of neuroscience, preparing students for a range of careers or further study.
classHighlights: The core curriculum includes Introduction to Neuroscience (NEUROSCI M101A), Cellular Neurobiology (NEUROSCI M101B), and Systems Neuroscience (NEUROSCI M101C), which provide a foundation in the principles of neuroscience.

Students also complete coursework in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (CHEM M153C or LIFE SCI M120), Psychology (PSYCH 100A or PSYCH 100B), and Statistics ( STATS 13 or PSYCH 100C), which provide a broad understanding of the underlying biological and psychological principles.

Additional required courses include Neurobiology Laboratory (NEUROSCI 101L), Neuroscience Research Methods (NEUROSCI 102), and Senior Seminar (NEUROSCI 199), which provide hands-on experience with experimental techniques and research methods.
learningOutcomes: Understand the fundamental principles of neuroscience, including the structure and function of the nervous system.
Apply knowledge of neuroscience to understand behavior and cognition.
Analyze and interpret data related to neuroscience.
Communicate complex ideas in neuroscience effectively in written and oral form.
Demonstrate an understanding of the research methods and techniques used in neuroscience.
additionalInformation: Students are advised to consult with a departmental advisor to ensure that they meet the requirements for the major.
